Award.AwardTitle: Foundations for Advancing STEM Teaching in Rural School Districts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this project aims to serve the national interest in high quality STEM teaching by investigating the STEM teaching needs of rural Iowa. The project involves a partnership between Upper Iowa University, local high-need school districts, and Northeast Iowa Community College. This partnership will define local teacher workforce needs and develop new recruiting strategies to interest STEM majors in teaching. It will build stronger pathways to teaching careers for community college students and identify supports that can help STEM majors become successful STEM teachers. Information produced by the project can inform efforts to increase the number and quality of STEM teachers who can meet the needs of rural schools.

The activities of this project include surveys of local area school personnel, as well as focus groups with current STEM and education majors and alumni. The resulting data will provide insights into factors that support or hinder careers in STEM teaching at rural schools. The data will also document specific areas of STEM teacher shortage and inform the development of targeted recruiting strategies. Articulation agreements between Upper Iowa University and Northeast Iowa Community College will be strengthened by developing degree plans that enable STEM majors to graduate in four years with teacher certification and the skills to meet the needs of rural school districts. A review of existing academic support strategies for STEM majors will be conducted, and each strategy will be evaluated for potential success in the local context. Conference participation will enable project personnel to disseminate findings from the project and will inform the project of viable models in use elsewhere. A strong internal dissemination plan will ensure that information is shared with stakeholders directly engaged in the project and those whom the project intends to serve. The project may provide useful insights into affordances and constraints that arise in conjunction with the new All Science teacher endorsement area recently developed by the Iowa Department of Education. The NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become K-12 mathematics and science teachers in high-need school districts and in-service teachers to become STEM master teachers. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Foundations for Advancing STEM Teaching in Rural School Districts (FAST)

This National Science Foundation grant was awarded to Upper Iowa University (UIU) to examine the need for secondary science teachers in rural Iowa, the barriers to recruiting students intersted in becoming secondary science teachers, strategies to encourage STEM majors already in college to become secondary science teachers, and to create a plan for academic support for those students wishing to teach secondary science. A survey of administrators, counselors, and science teachers of area schools was completed and the data supported the need for secondary science teachers in rural Iowa. Reasons for unfilled science teacher positions included; preparation, hiring, low pay, and retention. A survey of current STEM majors not choosing science education indicated the wide variety of careers in the STEM field,the opportunity to conduct active science in the field, and low pay for teachers. Those educators who choose to teach science described the positive role models of their own science teachers and the challenge for them to make an impact on the education of young people. UIU and Northeast Iowa Community College (NICC) created a degree plan to streamline completion of the four-year degree to become a secondary science teacher. This plan will work for all Iowa community college students as the coursework is consistent at all Iowa community colleges. Current academic supports were examined and compared to similiar universities to support student success in obtaining the All Science degree with Teacher Licensure. Brochures, posters and a website were created as recruitment tools.
